author: Beth Abbit
title: OAP left critically ill in Dubai hospital after suffering near-fatal stroke facing jail after his business collapsed
text:
Malcome Munroe's wife Olga with their son Paul, 14 (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Share Get daily   
The family of a pensioner lying critically ill in a Dubai hospital are sent weekly photographs of their loved one because they face arrest if they ever attempt to visit him in person. 
Malcome Munroe's construction business collapsed after he suffered a near-fatal stroke in 2013 and he was handed a three-year jail term for unpaid debts. 
Relatives of the businessman, 70, who is too ill to leave hospital and is permanently connected to an oxygen tank, fear they will be arrested if they fly to Dubai because they are linked to his company. 
So his wife Olga and their sons Alexandre, 16, and Paul, 14, rely on a friend in the Middle Eastern country to send weekly photos of their loved one lying in his hospital bed. 
Family say Mr Munroe will never be able to serve his prison sentence as he can only just move his head, is fed through a tube and is permanently connected to an oxygen pump. Olga, who previously battled leukaemia, now faces the daily trauma of not being able to see her stricken husband (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Read More Police say 'female assassins' knew Kim Jong-nam murder wasn't TV prank as suspect linked to North Korean embassy 
The father-of-three, originally from Chorlton, Greater Manchester, has not seen his wife and sons for two years, the Manchester Evening News reported . 
Malcome’s sister, Diane Kirkwood, has appealed to MPs, the Foreign Office, the UK Embassy in Dubai and even Prince Charles in a bid to help her brother. 
Friends in Dubai have managed to raise thousands of pounds for a private helicopter to fly Malcome back to the UK. 
But family say the Dubai authorities must agree to release him before he can be brought back home to England. 
“It is heartbreaking for his wife, sons and us. We cannot go to visit him, we have to wait until somebody he knew in Dubai goes to see him then lets us know how he is and one person sends a photograph of him each week just lying in hospital,” Diane said. 
“He turned 70 last November and we wonder how much longer he can survive. His sons would dearly love to see their dad.” 
Malcome moved to Dubai in the 1980s for work and eventually set up his own construction company employing hundreds of men. 
While there he married his Ukrainian wife Olga and the couple had sons Alexandre and Paul. Olga and son Paul want the authorities in Dubai to let Malcome come home (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Read More Dubai police refuse to let British woman fly to UK for life-saving cancer treatment after passport confiscated 
When Olga was diagnosed with leukaemia, the family moved to Eccles, Greater Manchester, so she could undergo treatment at The Christie cancer hospital, which was successful. 
The boys were visiting Malcome in Dubai when he suffered a massive stroke just three days before Christmas in 2013. 
They were cared for by Diane and her husband in the UK while Olga kept a vigil by her husband’s bedside at Rashid Hospital. 
Malcome was placed in an induced coma and suffered nine more bleeds to the brain, almost dying on two occasions. 
While in hospital, Diane says the Dubai government closed Malcome’s company and several creditors came forward to bring cases against him. 
The case went to court over debts owed and he was handed a three-year prison sentence. 
Diane wrote a mercy letter to the judge begging him to send her brother home, but she never received a reply. 
When Diane and her husband asked the Foreign Office for advice about visiting Malcome, officials said they could not guarantee they would be able to pass through United Arab Emirates passport control without being stopped. 
She said: “Anybody connected with the company will be asked to pay the debts owed when they enter the country. Mr Munroe's family are sent weekly pictures from a friend already in Dubai (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Read More Mother and model daughter convicted of fraud plot after stealing identity of dead landlady and moving into millionairess's home 
"We wanted to visit for his 70th birthday but we were worried we would be stopped. We are worried we wouldn’t get any further than the airport. 
“The last time we saw him was October 2013 when he came to us here and said how peaceful it was. 
"We tried to persuade him to stay for Christmas but said ‘I have to go back for the men’. He could be flown back here but the decision has to come from Dubai - they have to release him.” 
Bedridden Mr Munroe is now conscious but has very limited movement and cannot speak. 
His family rely on a friend in Dubai who visits him to send pictures. 
The avid Manchester United fan, who ‘lived and breathed’ football, was pictured with a football top draped across his hospital bed on his 70th birthday. 
Diane said: “He moves his head from side to side and blinks, that’s it. Our friend says sometimes a tear will trickle down his face when he shows him pictures of the boys or Olga. Read More Brit jailed in Dubai after claiming she had been raped to help sex attack victims after raising £30,000 
“You close your eyes and just picture him lying there with no family there to see him.” 
Diane said the family are desperate to bring Mr Munroe back home to the UK where they believe he will be able to undergo rehabilitation and physiotherapy at Salford Royal Hospital. 
She is now calling on anyone with the legal expertise that could help to repatriate Mr Munroe to get in touch. 
“It is so sad to think his two sons, his wife and his family may never get to see him again. His family are in a mess and his sons are pining for him," she said. 
“We can’t afford to pay solicitors fees as my husband and I are both pensioners and Malcome’s wife can’t afford it. But we’d appreciate any advice. We never thought it would go on for so long.” 
The Embassy of the UAE has been approached for comment. Like us on Facebook
